guide.introduction:
Introduction

The beacon transmitter is controlled by a PicAxe 08M micro controller. The 08M keys the transmitter sending a Morse code message and a request for a QSL (acknowledge reception of signal. The beacon is battery powered and can be mounted on the antenna mast at the antenna feed point.

This project builds on the great 40 mW 10 Meter beacon built and tested by VK6HV. Using inexpensive, off-the-shelf components you can be on the air for under $10.Note: You must have an amateur radio license to operate this transmitter.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Introduction

The beacon transmitter is controlled by a PicAxe 08M micro controller. The 08M keys the transmitter sending a Morse code message and a request for a QSL (acknowledge reception of signal. The beacon is battery powered and can be mounted on the antenna mast at the antenna feed point.

This project builds on the great 40 mW 10 Meter beacon built and tested by VK6HV. Using inexpensive, off-the-shelf components you can be on the air for under $10.Note: You must have an amateur radio license to operate this transmitter.

Relevant parts
  • Plastic box (A) 4"x4"x5"high or similar.
  • Battery Holder (B) for 4 AAA rechargeable Batteries
  • (C) Assembled PicAxe 08M Protoboard with chip.
  • 28.322 MHz clock crystal (D)
  • Double-sided foam mounting squares (E).
Tools
  • 5/8 Drill bit and drill press or hand drill and vise.
  • Eye protection
  • Soldering Iron and rosin core solder.
